snippet.textDisplay: Excellent video and I cannot thank you enough for producing it. As an ecologist, I understand exponential growth as it is fundamental to so many aspects of ecology. Unfortunately trying to explain it to people without this background is very difficult to almost impossible. They simply have no grasp of this type of slow start and rapid acceleration you get with exponential growth. So they mistakenly think because at first new infections and deaths are only growing slowly, that it is not a problem and is being over-exaggerated at a problem. This is all because it is counter-intuitive to their way of thinking. I will share it widely.

snippet.textDisplay: This whole thing has made me lose faith in people. The ignorant, stupid, evil and selfish have come out the woodwork. I've seen people saying it's not a big deal. Others saying they dont care about people dying; people saying it's a conspiracy, saying it doesn't exist or it's to control us; people stocking up without a single thought of others. The number of people who are believing fake news or their own, ridiculous theories is frightening. This whole thing has made me realise humanity hasn't moved on from ancient civilisations, at all. We're just as stupid as selfish as ever.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm afraid you are making the problem worse by showing incorrect charts. Both these options are actually bad.

Yes, it is good to "flatten the curve" but it isn't enough. The capacity of the health care system on your chart is unrealistic. Realistic capacity with regard to this virus is far below both of these curves, even the flattened one. The health care system will collapse quite soon even with a slow epidemic because 10-15% of infected need to be hospitalized. If you look at Italy, they only have a few percent of population infected and their system is already collapsing. The only valid strategy is to reduce R0 far below 1 and contain the epidemic ASAP. This will reduce the total number of infected people which at this point is still far below 1% in most countries. There is still time so the sooner the better. Otherwise there will be many deaths.

Lets assume that if there were no countermeasures the epidemic would run for 12 months and it would infect 60-70% population in total. There would be 3-5% deaths, probably more because the system couldn't handle the 10-15% of infected and mortality goes up once that happens. If we flatten the curve and spread the epidemic for 24 months with the same number of total infections we only reduce the load by 50% which is still clearly far above the capacity. With 36 months it's only down by 30%. First of all, these are extremely long timeframes with regard to quarantine measures, but more importantly the hospitals would still get overwhelmed even with such reductions.
snippet.textOriginal:

The health care system will collapse quite soon even with a slow epidemic because 10-15% of infected need to be hospitalized. If you look at Italy, they only have a few percent of population infected and their system is already collapsing. The only valid strategy is to reduce R0 far below 1 and contain the epidemic ASAP. This will reduce the total number of infected people which at this point is still far below 1% in most countries. There is still time so the sooner the better. Otherwise there will be many deaths.

Lets assume that if there were no countermeasures the epidemic would run for 12 months and it would infect 60-70% population in total. There would be 3-5% deaths, probably more because the system couldn't handle the 10-15% of infected and mortality goes up once that happens. If we flatten the curve and spread the epidemic for 24 months with the same number of total infections we only reduce the load by 50% which is still clearly far above the capacity. With 36 months it's only down by 30%. First of all, these are extremely long timeframes with regard to quarantine measures, but more importantly the hospitals would still get overwhelmed even with such reductions.

snippet.textDisplay: We have to find a balance. We can't just permanently shut down the economy because every year there's a new flu virus and a flat curve may take a whole year to run its course, or even multiple years. At this point the media has everybody in a panic. That's not good. And all this fuss over a virus that isn't fatal for healthy people. Yes, you'll get sick. No, it won't be pleasant. But unless your immune system is already compromised you won't die. To be honest there are far deadlier diseases out there that we don't shut down the economy for. We need to take reasonable precautions without going overboard and shutting everything down.
snippet.textOriginal: We have to find a balance. We can't just permanently shut down the economy because every year there's a new flu virus and a flat curve may take a whole year to run its course, or even multiple years. At this point the media has everybody in a panic. That's not good. And all this fuss over a virus that isn't fatal for healthy people. Yes, you'll get sick. No, it won't be pleasant. But unless your immune system is already compromised you won't die. To be honest there are far deadlier diseases out there that we don't shut down the economy for. We need to take reasonable precautions without going overboard and shutting everything down.

snippet.textDisplay: Isn't the issue more so that we need to control the spread in specific populations though? If we focus on isolating those populations using the larger amount of resources available because people are still functioning and those who are ok are not pulling those resources, create a herd immunity within the non affected community, and slowly reintroduce  the vulnerable populations slowly or after we have a vaccine wouldn't  that be more effective and less destructive? This isn't smallpox, this is a much more benign virus for those who are healthy, and allowing those people to catch it will provide us with the needed immunity and manpower to push the infection rate down.

snippet.textDisplay:
Flattening the curve is similar to how electric utilities try to offset and shave peak loading - the overall energy used during the day is the same, but the maximum power is lower.
Until recently I wrote software for this, and another similarity is how it requires a centralized execution, to tell everybody (or, rather for autonomous dispatch over the internet to smart appliances) that "hey, you don't need to heat that water so much right now" or "hey, you should pre-cool your house before the heat wave peaks" (or pre-heat for cold snaps) in Demand Response programs.
Unlike Demand Response programs however, there is no "pre-heating/cooling" strategy, and there are some other ways my analogy breaks down too. Instead, we /kinda of/ only have the "ramping/randomization" strategy.
snippet.textOriginal:

Unlike Demand Response programs however, there is no "pre-heating/cooling" strategy, and there are some other ways my analogy breaks down too. Instead, we /kinda of/ only have the "ramping/randomization" strategy.

snippet.textDisplay:
I live in the corona virus stronghold in Germany. In my workplace some of the staff is already isolated at home for 5 weeks, the 3 shifts in production are isolated from one another... We try to stop it... but there are isolated employees who still meet with friends, visit their old parents or friends with children...

The corona virus is going to get a lot worse, because you can't rely on people to take care of other people. You can impose curfews, close borders and appeal to people, but there will always be some fool ... who manages to spread the virus.

I was reading these messages and someone asked how do you build up your immune system to avoid a virus , so I thought putting the message here where everyone can read it would be helpful

you can build your immune system by taking vitamin C and vitamin D3 daily also by consuming more fruits and veggies and I'm not talking "an apple a day to keep the Doctor away" it means eating several different fruits a day and eating these a couple of times a day same with veggies , steamed veggies are better tasting then boiled and have more nutrients raw veggies are even better for you then steamed !
a one cup serving is a half a cup , your dinner plate should have two servings of veggies exercise is also good so take a walk

if you start this to avoid covid-19 don't start getting lax in the other recommendations like washing your hands , social distancing ( keep two meters or six feet away from other people) , stay out of large crowds because you never know who might be a carrier and not affected by the infection even a carrier doesn't know they are a carrier!

snippet.textDisplay:
I believe this pandemic has showed us something we can not ignore anymore: If when someone in China "sneezes" the whole world gets sick, than we can't just be sitting in our living rooms and watch diasaters happen on the other side of the world on tv while having our dinner anymore. This virus doesn't care if you are white, black, middle eastern, jewish or asian. It doesnt care have much money you have or who you voted for. This Virus sees us as humans that is good enough for it. Unless we do the same this wont be the last disaster we end up being unprepared for. Disease, war, famine, injustice, terrorism, ignorence, racism, intolerance, these are all of our problems. Either we will thrive as speices or will will go down together.
Stay safe everyone. Love from Istanbul.

This Virus sees us as humans that is good enough for it. Unless we do the same this wont be the last disaster we end up being unprepared for.  Disease, war, famine, injustice, terrorism, ignorence, racism, intolerance, these are all of our problems. Either we will thrive as speices or will will go down together.  
Stay safe everyone. Love from Istanbul.

snippet.textDisplay:
The media sensationalism was no joke. Every news station, every talk show, every everything was talking about death-scenarios from the beginning which caused people to panic and go buy out the stores, but they didn't provide any useful information - what was really happening, what might happen, and how to prevent it. There was no news about social distancing, or that we didn't need to stock up 6 months of toilet paper, or that you shouldn't rush to the hospital unless you are having severe shortness of breath because the healthcare system cannot handle everyone coming in at once, or that you shouldn't be stealing supplies from the hospitals, or that wearing masks isn't helpful, or that wearing gloves doesn't help if you wear them everywhere and touch everything (including yourself) with them.



It was lots of "EVERYONE IS DYING!" and "THIS IS WAAAAAY WORSE THAN THE FLU!" and "DEMOCRATS/REPUBLICANS ARE TO BLAME FOR EVERYTHING!" Also, because of rampant distrust of the media, many people have blown off all worries as fear mongering and go about their business as if nothing is wrong. Most media networks have done nothing to help this crisis. They've only made things worse.
snippet.textOriginal:
The media sensationalism was no joke. Every news station, every talk show, every everything was talking about death-scenarios from the beginning which caused people to panic and go buy out the stores, but they didn't provide any useful information - what was really happening, what might happen, and how to prevent it. There was no news about social distancing, or that we didn't need to stock up 6 months of toilet paper, or that you shouldn't rush to the hospital unless you are having severe shortness of breath because the healthcare system cannot handle everyone coming in at once, or that you shouldn't be stealing supplies from the hospitals, or that wearing masks isn't helpful, or that wearing gloves doesn't help if you wear them everywhere and touch everything (including yourself) with them. 



It was lots of "EVERYONE IS DYING!" and "THIS IS WAAAAAY WORSE THAN THE FLU!" and "DEMOCRATS/REPUBLICANS ARE TO BLAME FOR EVERYTHING!" Also, because of rampant distrust of the media, many people have blown off all worries as fear mongering and go about their business as if nothing is wrong. Most media networks have done nothing to help this crisis. They've only made things worse.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why does this video present the outbreak as an over reaction when its very clearly an 'UNDER reaction'?
We've had plenty of opportunities to learn these lessons from stuff like bird flu and SARS....so why are governments still waiting almost a MONTH to start taking real serious responses to these things? Based on what this video talks about (which isn't new information to experts by the way)...it illustrates how much of a massive fail the globe was in terms of reacting to this.



When we get through this...I'm curious just how much things will change for the next one. Will the world be on top of it taking precautions in week 1? Or will it once again not be our problem until cases start to appear and grow rapidly in our country?

snippet.textDisplay: The economy cannot be shut down so the curve can flatten out over months.  The central question is how many more deaths with a large and quick curve compared to deaths of a small and drawn out curve?  If that number of deaths is under 100K, is it worth destroying the economy?  Under 500K?  1 million?  Keep in mind any number under 3 million is still less than 1% of our population?  It's an uncomfortable question I know, but we don't destroy the economy over highway deaths or flu deaths or deaths from falling on stairs.   That's a combined 200K deaths per year we don't flinch at.  So why shut down the economy over this new virus when the death toll is likely much lower than other acceptable death rates in other areas?
snippet.textOriginal: The economy cannot be shut down so the curve can flatten out over months.  The central question is how many more deaths with a large and quick curve compared to deaths of a small and drawn out curve?  If that number of deaths is under 100K, is it worth destroying the economy?  Under 500K?  1 million?  Keep in mind any number under 3 million is still less than 1% of our population?  It's an uncomfortable question I know, but we don't destroy the economy over highway deaths or flu deaths or deaths from falling on stairs.   That's a combined 200K deaths per year we don't flinch at.  So why shut down the economy over this new virus when the death toll is likely much lower than other acceptable death rates in other areas?
